cluster_classes.class_description: Body posture and specific postural patterns used as nonverbal signals, including generic posture and particular upright or slouched positions associated with social meaning.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Posture as a body position in body language, including standing up straight, slouching, and maintaining good posture.

members.entity_description: The way a person holds and aligns their body, functioning as a component of body language and a nonverbal cue that can communicate attitudes, emotions, and engagement in social interactions.

members.entity_name: standing up straight with shoulders back
members.entity_description: A specific upright posture with retracted shoulders commonly associated with confidence and assertiveness.
A posture characterized by drooping shoulders or a curved back, often interpreted negatively.
Upright, aligned body position used to convey confidence and authority.

cluster_classes.class_description: Instances where individuals signal authority or leadership in professional contexts through body language cues such as posture and eye contact.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: project confidence and authority by maintaining good posture and making direct eye contact

members.entity_description: Perceived power or leadership status signaled through professional body language.

args.new_description: Nonverbal body language signals centered on posture (e.g., upright stance, slouching, good posture) and the social impressions they create, such as confidence and perceived authority in professional or social contexts.
args.justification: Both classes concern nonverbal communication through posture and closely related professional body-language signals, and the smaller class contains only a single authority-related outcome, so consolidating them avoids a trivial, overlapping class and yields a coherent posture-and-authority-cues category.

The merged class covers posture-based nonverbal signals and their associated impressions (confidence, authority), which fits within a broader Nonverbal Communication & Body Language group rather than remaining ungrouped (TBD).

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes concern nonverbal communication through posture and closely related professional body-language signals, and the smaller class contains only a single authority-related outcome, so consolidating them avoids a trivial, overlapping class and yields a coherent posture-and-authority-cues category.

The merged class covers posture-based nonverbal signals and their associated impressions (confidence, authority), which fits within a broader Nonverbal Communication & Body Language group rather than remaining ungrouped (TBD).
